node.title: A Janitor’s Colleagues Put Him on the Fast Track to Retirement
node.alt: Alfredo Lupi, fifth from right, poses with his co-workers on Thursday at the Senna Inox factory in Graffignana, Italy.
node.description: An Italian factory worker was dealing with a lifelong impairment that made it hard to work, but he wasn’t in a position to retire. Then his co-workers gave him 20 months’ worth of vacation days.
node.content: ["At 64, Alfredo Lupi, a janitor at a factory in Graffignana, an industrial town southeast of Milan, was less than three years away from his retirement, a threshold that was at once incredibly close but impossibly far.", "A cognitive impairment that he had suffered from almost since birth was making his job more difficult by the day. The condition was too debilitating for him to work without discomfort, but quitting would have been hard to afford without a pension.", "That\u2019s where his co-workers came in.", "One evening earlier this month, after his shift ended, the employees of the Senna Inox factory gathered to unveil a surprise for Mr. Lupi. He could retire early. In fact, he could retire now.", "Bewildered at first, Mr. Lupi slowly understood. \u201cYou gave me my pension,\u201d he said, visibly moved. \u201cThank you.\u201d", "Technically, his colleagues gave him something else: Vacation days. They had transferred some of their own allotment \u2014 some gave more days, some gave less, but all gave something. That allowed him to stop working, but meant he could remain on the books at the Senna Inox factory and collect a salary until he reached the retirement age of 67.", "\u201cIn the last few months, he was visibly tired and had a hard time working,\u201d said Piera, one of Mr. Lupi\u2019s colleagues, who declined to give her last name because she did not want publicity for herself. \u201cThis was a collective effort. We all felt it was not fair that if he quit, he would have to stay home with no paycheck for two years.\u201d", "The practice of donating personal vacation days to colleagues in need is increasing popular in Italy. In recent years, the story of a mother who was given the equivalent of three years to take care of her disabled son, as well as tales of time-off donated to hospital workers who have young children and no time to spend with them, have made headlines in Italy.", "But Mr. Lupi\u2019s case was unusual because all 50 of his colleagues pitched in, collecting 20 months worth of working days. \u201cWe gave up a little of our free time, yes,\u201d Piera said. \u201cBut this was more important.\u201d", "Still, for all of their generosity, the employees hadn\u2019t collected enough time, but Senna Inox rounded things off by agreeing to pay him for the remaining year he would need to reach retirement age.", "\u201cYou might see it as a big present, but we see it as an investment in solidarity,\u201d said Pietro Senna, one of the four brothers who run the factory founded by their grandfather in 1950. \u201cWe are not depriving ourselves of anything, quite the opposite.\u201d", "Mr. Senna said that the vast majority of their employees at the factory, which designs and produces equipment for the pharmaceutical and food production industry, work there for their entire careers.", "\u201cWe like each other\u201d and consider the work a mission, he said. \u201cI go nowhere without them, and we are there when they need us.\u201d", "Mr. Lupi has always been a fixture in Graffignana, which has a population of about 2,600 and is where the N.B.A. star Danilo Gallinari grew up.", "Mr. Lupi normally participated in the town\u2019s social activities, playing the shepherd in the annual Dec. 13 celebrations for St. Lucy \u2014 the bearer of the light in the winter darkness, and a particularly beloved saint in northern Italy \u2014 that a local parish organizes for children. Afterward, Mr. Lupi would bring candies to his colleagues at the factory.", "\u201cWe are fewer than 2,600 people here, so solidarity is natural,\u201d said Margherita Muzzi, the mayor of mayor of Graffignana.", "Alessandro Lupi, 51, Alfredo\u2019s brother and a colleague at Senna Inox, where he is a technical manager, said he was a bit perplexed when his colleagues told him of their plan.", "\u201cI feared retiring would not be good for him,\u201d he said. \u201cHe needs to have people around him and maybe being at home with our mother would be isolating for him with time.\u201d", "But Mr. Senna reassured him that Alfredo could come visit whenever he liked.", "\u201cHe said that the doors here are wide-open for Alfredo,\u201d Mr. Lupi said. \u201cAnd so are their hearts.\u201d"]
